quote: If you're not too busy, I'd    appreciate it if you did something    about that shipment of Livanian    beets you have sitting in Cargo    Bay Three.
It's been there for over two    weeks. It's starting to rot.        Morn.
It's a hologram.        Morn's been away on business for    the last two weeks.
You're slipping, Odo. You    should've caught on a lot sooner.
You replaced Morn with a hologram?    Why?
Hello.
Evening.
That's why. People love him.    He's like a mascot. Everyone    expects to see him when they come    in here. If they don't, it    doesn't feel like home to them.
And that's not good for business.
The last time he went away sales    dropped almost five percent.
Why doesn't it talk?

Do you have any idea how much an    interactive holo-projector costs?    (sotto, so Bashir and    O'Brien can't hear)   Besides, it's a relief not to have   to listen to him go on. You know   Morn, he never shuts up.        I'd trade this for the real thing    any day.
I'm sure Morn would be touched to    hear you say that.
Morn?
It's just a hologram.
You look like you've seen a ghost.
Turn it off.
Why?
We just got word. Morn's cargo    ship was caught in an ion storm.
Is he all right?
Was he rescued?
He's dead...
Didn't you bring anything?    (off O'Brien's blank     look)    For the memorial service.
I didn't know I was supposed to.
It's Lurian custom to bring gifts    of food and drink for the deceased --    so they'll have something to    sustain them in the afterlife.
Maybe I can get something in    Quark's. I hate to think of the    big fella going without.
Morn was an excellent sparring    partner. I will miss our weekly    combat in the holosuites.
I can't believe he's really gone.
I didn't realize he was such a   close friend.
I used to have a little crush on   him.
Morn?
It was before we met.       Besides, he wasn't interested.
What do you mean he wasn't   interested?
Forget I said anything.
Is that a bottle opener?
For Morn. I thought it might come   in handy.
Very thoughtful.
This is unbelievable. Look at all   these people.       If you see anyone emptyhanded   sell them a bottle of Yridian Ale.
Tell them it was Morn's favorite.
It was kind of you to do this,   Quark.
Morn would've appreciated it.
It's the least I could do.
I'll miss him.
I'm sorry.
Can I get you something?
I don't ordinarily imbibe on the    job. But maybe a Yridian Ale. It    was Morn's favorite, you know.
Perfect.
What are you looking at?
Your respect for the dead is    heartwarming.
I'll have you know that Morn died    without paying this month's tab.
How inconsiderate of him.
We're talking about a lot of    money. The man had quite an    appetite -- he had two stomachs to    fill, you know.        Did you ever watch him eat? It    was a beautiful thing.
Sometimes you don't truly    appreciate what you have until    it's gone.
It's not funny. This service is    my only chance to cover my losses.
Morn seemed to be a fairly    successful businessman.
If you come up short, you can    always make a claim against his    estate.
I hadn't thought of that.
Of course, he did have seventeen    brothers and sisters. By the time    they divvy everything up, I doubt    there'll be much left.
It's nice to know you're so    worried about my welfare.
You should be worried, too. Now    that your mascot is gone, business    is going to suffer.
We'll see.        You might be surprised.
Jadzia --
Can we please drop this?
Thank you all for coming.

It means a great deal to me to see    that so many people cared about    Morn as much as I did. I'll never    forget the first time he walked in    here and sat down on this very    stool. It must've been almost ten    years ago -- he still had his hair    then. I thought he was just    another customer passing through.    Little did I know that he'd become    such an important figure in my    life, in all our lives. Someone    we could count on for a cheerful    smile and an entertaining story.    Some of you might be thinking that    this place won't be the same    without him. And it won't.         But this was his home.

And wherever he is, I'm sure he'd    want to know that his favorite bar    still echoed with the laughter of    his dear friends.        This was his chair... and I think    the greatest tribute we could ever    pay him would be to make sure that    it's never empty.
Keep it warm. For Morn.
Every now and then, Quark really    surprises me...
Me, too.
Excuse me, Quark.
Not now.
I'm sorry to intrude, but I    thought you should know.
I unsealed Morn's will. He left    everything to you.
Me? He left everything to me?
That's right.
Morn... dear sweet, Morn...
Poor fool. He actually believed    you cared about him.
I did.    (almost convinced of it    himself)   I was up for hours last night   thinking about him.
Calculating his net worth, no    doubt.
We spent a lot of time together.    We were obviously much closer than    I ever realized.
His financial records.
Is this some kind of joke?
What do you mean?
According to this, he was broke.
No.
How can that be? He paid his bar    bill at the end of every month --    that kind of money must've come    from somewhere.
He did have his shipping business.    Maybe all his assets are tied up    in inventory?
Of course! Inventory.
I'll unload everything and use the    profits to --        What is that smell?
Your inheritance.        Livanian beets. Very ripe.
What's in the rest of these?
More beets.
Is that it, is that all he had?
I'm afraid so.
(as if it were just     occurring to him)   Except for the contents of his   quarters. Maybe he spent all his   money on furnishings and art work.
Objets d'art. Of course!
I'll hold an auction... people   will pay a premium to own   something that used to be Morn's.
You sure these are the right   quarters?
I'm sure.
Figures.    (looking around, sees     painting)   What's that?
A matador, I think.
That.
His bed.
Morn slept in mud?
I'm told it's good for the skin...
Thanks, Morn... just what I always   wanted...
What are you doing in my mud?
I couldn't resist. Morny and I    spent so many happy hours here, I    just had to slip in. I'm sorry if    I startled you, but when I heard    you come in I thought I'd better    hide.
Who are you?
(as if he should     recognize the name)    Larell.        Morn's wife. Ex-wife.
Morn was married? To you?
For two wonderful years.
You must be Quark.        Morny and I kept in touch after we    separated. He talked about you    all the time.
That's nice.
He told me that if anything ever    happened to him, he wanted you to    have everything that was ever his.
Everything?
Everything.
I'm glad you came by, because    "Morny" didn't leave me much of    anything else.
I find that hard to believe...
I'm as disappointed as you are.
I happen to know he had a very    substantial retirement fund. One    that could make two people very    comfortable.
If you're partial to mud, it's    comfortable all right.
I'm talking about the thousand    bricks of gold-pressed latinum he    won in the Lissepian Lottery.
A thousand bricks...
Now that he's gone, it's all    ours...
(sliding her hand around     his waist)    What are you doing... ?
(sloshing the mud around     so he can see)    What do you think -- I'm looking    for the latinum.
You must know where he kept it.
I didn't even know it existed    until you told me.
Well, I'm sure it's somewhere on    the station.
How do you know he didn't spend it    already?
I told you, it was for his    retirement. Poor Morn. He never    got to enjoy it.
But that doesn't mean we can't.
I know what you're doing...
What am I doing?
Just so we're clear, the latinum's mine.
(through a cobra's    smile)   He may have left everything to   you, but I was his wife -- I could   contest the will and tie you up in   court for years...
Maybe.
But there's no reason it should    come to that... after all, a    thousand bricks is plenty for both    of us.
It is a lot of money...
And as soon as we find it, we'll    take a nice long vacation    together.
Morn would've wanted it that way.
Of course he would've...
The latinum's not on the station.    I've looked everywhere.        Evade.        I even had my brother scan for it    with the internal sensors.
At least you have the painting.
Forget the painting, I want that    latinum.
If you think it'll make you happy.        Confront.
Believe me, it will. This is the    break I've been waiting for, and    it's been a long time coming. I    want Morn's money, I need Morn's   money. I deserve Morn's money.
Your move.
Beautiful, isn't it? And the way    it catches the light...        I wonder who came up with the idea    of suspending liquid latinum    inside worthless bricks of gold?
Probably somebody who got tired of    making change with an eyedropper.    Are you going to play or not?
Where could Morn have put it all?
If you find it, are you really    going to share it with this woman?
I agreed to give her ten percent    so she wouldn't tie me up in    court.
That's a hundred bricks.
What could I do?        Retreat.
I don't know. Something's not    right about this whole thing.
I don't trust this woman.
Neither do I. But that doesn't   mean I'm going to keep her away   from my lobes.
Just keep your eyes open.       Don't be fooled by a pretty face.
Not me.
Of course not.       Acquire.
Larell?       What a pleasant surprise.       Computer, lights.
Do you like surprises, Quark?
Only pleasant ones.
I like to think I'm pleasant.       Do you think I'm pleasant?
Absolutely.
Then I guess this qualifies as a   pleasant surprise.
What are you doing in my quarters?
My brother and I were business   associates of Morn's.
If you came for the memorial   service, it was yesterday.
Was it nice?
It was lovely.
I understand you inherited Morn's    estate.
That's right.
We were business associates of    Morn's.
Your brother mentioned that.
He borrowed some money from us.    We'd like his estate to repay the    loan.
How much money are we talking    about?
One thousand bricks of gold-   pressed latinum.
I had a feeling you were going to    say that.
Obviously I need to see some    documentation regarding this loan.
We shook hands.
(moving to stand behind    Quark)    We trusted Morn.
And I'm sure he'd want you to    honor his word.
I'm sure he would. But you have    to understand, Morn's assets are    tied up in his various enterprises.
I hope you're not saying you don't    have the money.
That wouldn't be good.
All I meant was that it's going to    take me a little while to get it.
You do know where it is?
Of course.
However, you're not the first    creditors to make a claim against    his estate.
We're not?

Morn was expanding his business    interests when he died. His    resources were stretched somewhat    thin. As a result, the claims    against his estate are greater    than its assets. Obviously you    can't expect full repayment.
What can we expect?
A percentage.
What sort of percentage?
Twenty.
We couldn't accept anything less    than eighty.
I don't like beets.
We'll take seventy.
Forty, and because I can see you    both have fine taste, I'm willing    to part with this.
It was Morn's most treasured   possession. Beautiful, isn't it?
Nice.
We won't take less than sixty.
Forty's the best I can do.
Fifty.
Sorry.
Fifty it is.
I'm glad we were able to come to   an understanding.
Me too.
We'll be watching you, Quark.   Don't try anything.
Me? Don't be ridiculous.
What do we have here... ?
Computer, what is this?
A claim slip for storage locker   one-thirty-seven located in the   station's Assay Office.
A storage locker...       Thank you, computer. You've been   very helpful.
Morn, wherever you are, I love    you!
What do you mean I have to open it    in here?
Regulations -- the contents of a    deceased person's storage locker    have to be inspected by station    security.
There's no such regulation, you    just want to know what's inside.
You are so transparent. I can't    wait to see your face when your    deputies wheel in my thousand    bricks of latinum.
That can't be it.
(checks the label,     smiles)    Storage locker one-thirty-seven.
Well, sometimes good things come    in small packages...
Is that going to be enough to   cover Morn's bar tab?
It's covered.       There's more where this came from.
What makes you say that?
Take a look.
On the bottom.       Recognize Morn's handwriting?
"The rest is in the Bank of   Bolias."
Account number CJ57436.
It wasn't listed in Morn's    financial records...

Who cares?    (tucking the brick into     his vest)    Now if you'll excuse me, I'm going    to contact the bank and let them    know that Morn's legal heir would    like his latinum delivered as soon    as possible...
Larell...
I've been looking all over for    you...
I'm a busy man.
Not too busy to look for a certain    something, I hope?
Actually, I haven't had much luck    with that.
Sounds like you need some    motivation...

I'm motivated, believe me. It's    just going to take some time to    locate, that's all.        I've got an idea! Why don't you    go back to... wherever you came    from -- and I'll contact you as    soon as I find it.
I'd rather wait here.        With you.
This is no time for oo-mox...
You don't like it?
It's not that, it's just... the    sooner I find that certain    something, the sooner you and I    can take our little trip together.
You're so diligent. Most men    don't know how to defer    gratification.
You don't make it easy...
Level Seventeen.
You're good. But I'm the only one    the bank's going to give the money    to.    (repeating the number so     he won't forget)   CJ57436. CJ57436. CJ5 --
This is my stop.
What's your hurry?
My brother has something he wants    to say to you.
I'm sorry.        About the painting.
He feels terrible.
(trying to move past     them)    No hard feelings.
It's nice of you to be so    forgiving, Quark.
Don't mention it.
My brother has a terrible temper.
I get upset.
It comes out when things don't go    our way.
I noticed.
That's why I'm hoping things start    to go our way soon. Do you    understand what I'm saying?
I think I do, yes.
I don't like to get upset.
Don't worry, things are going to   go your way soon.
That's good to hear.
I'll be in touch.
Sorry about the painting.
--36. CJ57436.       Bank of Bolias...
Making a withdrawal, Quark? Let    me guess -- a thousand bricks of    gold-pressed latinum.
Put your hands on your head and    turn around.
All right, how much do you want?        And don't ask for the whole    thousand bricks, I already gave    away more than half of it.
Attempted bribery. That should    add a few years to your sentence.
What are you talking about?
Let's go.
Go where? Who are you?
Lurian Security. I have a signed    extradition order for your arrest.    (waving him toward the    door again)   As soon as your station's security   chief approves it, we'll be on our   way.
But what did I do -- what's the   charge?
Conspiracy to intercept government   property.
Government property?
One thousand bricks of gold   pressed latinum.
Wait a minute. Morn won that   latinum in the Lissepian lottery.
He didn't?
It was his bequest from the royal   family of Luria.
Why would the royal family of   Luria give Morn that kind of   money?
He was the crown prince.
Morn was a prince?
You didn't know?
Morn was a prince?
That's what I'm saying.
Morn was a prince...
Yes. But he renounced the throne   when he came of age.
I always knew he was an idiot.
His family bequeathed him the    latinum when he abdicated. Now    that he's deceased, it's legally    theirs again.
He left it to me.
The will has already been    nullified. He signed an agreement    to return the latinum in the event    of his death.
Oh.        Do me a favor, don't tell his ex-   wife that. I'm going to need a    little oo-mox later.
His ex-wife?
Larell.
She's here?
I just saw her.
Something wrong?
Quiet. Let me think.

Listen and listen carefully.    Larell has been trying to get her    hands on the Prince's latinum for    years. She's tried blackmail,    extortion -- I wouldn't be    surprised if she was behind his    death.
She's always been nice to me...
The royal family would like   nothing better than to see her    behind bars. If you help me    apprehend her, there'll be a    substantial reward.
What do I have to do?
When are you going to see her    again?
She'll turn up sooner or later.        If not her, those two brothers.
Brothers?
They said they were Morn's    business partners. They claim he    owed them money.        Something tells me they're not    exactly above board.
Whoever these brothers are, I    promise you I'm not going to let    them get between the royal family    and its latinum.
And I'm not going to let anything    get between me and my reward.
Then we have an understanding.
If I'm going to put these people    away, I need to catch them trying    to get their hands on the latinum.    Contact the bank -- tell them to    deliver it here.
Then what?
Try to stay out of sight. Leave    the rest to me.
What are you doing?
Trying to fix this optronic relay.
Wouldn't you be better off working    in a lab?
I'm keeping Morn's chair warm.
Good man.
Where's Quark? I'm in the mood    for one of his famous Til'amin    froths.
You'll have to settle for    something else. He's in the back.    (motioning to a Ferengi     waiter)    And from what Broik tells me, he's    not coming out.
Sounds like he's taking Morn's    death pretty hard.
He loved the guy.        I'd better go test this.
I'll take over.
Good man.
Anybody here?
What a surprise...
You've got to help me, Quark.   Someone's been following me.
Who?
Two men.
Brothers?
How should I know?
That could be them.
Don't answer it.
Believe me, I'm not planning to.
They're trying to bypass the lock.
Come on.
Computer, dim lights.
Remind me to invest in a better   lock...
Stay here.
Gentlemen.
We've been looking all over for    you, Quark.
The latinum's on its way. It'll    be here tomorrow.
That's good news. We were    starting to worry.
Expecting anyone?
You never know when someone's    going to drop by.
Don't answer it.
Sounds like they're coming in    anyway.
You should invest in a better    lock.
Whoever it is, get rid of them.    (indicating the     partition)   We'll be back there.
You'd be more comfortable in   there.
We'll be back there.
Why didn't you answer the door?
I dozed off. It's been one of   those days.
We need to talk.
What would we have to talk about?
Are you all right?
What makes you ask that?
You keep craning your neck.
Well look what we have here...
I'll bet the royal family sleeps    soundly knowing you're on the    job...
Royal family? What kind of lies    have you been telling him, Hain?
The usual.
You know each other?
It's been a long time.
Must be nine years.
Nine years.
I see you're still one step behind    everyone else.
Leave him alone, Hain.
It's Larell.
I can see that.
What is going on here?
We're having a little reunion.    (lowering Nahsk's     weapon)   We used to work together. With   Morn.
I guess that means he wasn't   really a Prince after all.
And you're not really a security   agent?
And you're not really his ex-wife?
Please don't tell me Morn didn't   have any latinum.
Oh, he had latinum, all right.
At least that part's true...
Ever hear of the Lissepian   Mother's Day heist?

Who hasn't? While the whole    planet was celebrating, someone    broke into the Central Bank and    made off with --    (realizing as he says     it)    One thousand bricks of gold-   pressed latinum.        Wait a minute. You expect me to    believe that the four of you    pulled that off?
(not realizing they've     been insulted)    The five of us. Morn helped.
Yeah, and then he ran off with the    latinum.
Why did it take you so long to    come after him?
Because we knew he'd stashed it    away somewhere to wait for the    statute of limitations to expire.
And it did. Two weeks ago.
You see, we can't be prosecuted    anymore.
So... here we are. And the    latinum's en route.        Maybe we should just split it up    and go our separate ways.
The voice of reason.
Not you, us.
Krit's right, we don't need him    anymore.
You know, we don't need him    anymore.
What do we do with him?
It should look like an accident.    We don't want anyone asking    questions.
Wait a minute. You can't kill me.    I'm the only one who can take    delivery of the latinum.        You need my thumbprint.
He's right.
It won't hurt as much if you keep    still.
What do you propose we do, Nahsk?    Walk into the cargo bay with a    bloody thumb and ask for the    latinum?
We need him.
The question is, what happens    after he takes delivery?
We could split the latinum five    ways.        It's what you would've gotten if    Morn was still alive.
True.
Think of me as Morn.        I can't believe I just said that.
It's not fair. We stole it. He    didn't do anything.
Maybe not. But the bottom line    is, you need me.
A thousand bricks, split five    ways... what do you think?
It's still a lot of latinum.
Two hundred and fifty bricks each.
So, do we have a deal?
He's in.
The Bolian transport arrives    tomorrow at sixteen hundred hours.        We'll meet at the cargo bay.
We're staying together until it    gets here.
We are?
I don't trust you, and I certainly    don't trust them.
I see your point. But I have a    bar to run.
(raising his glass to     Quark)    To your hospitality.
Don't mention it.
So this was Morn's favorite    place...
(pointing to Morn's     chair)    He used to sit right there.
That's not very smart -- sitting    with your back to the door.
He was the trusting type.
Which one of you killed him,    anyway?
Come on, it's nothing to be    ashamed of.
It wasn't us.
Me neither.
Don't look at me.
So it really was an accident.
Poor Morny. He always did have    bad luck.
We had some good times together...
He was always so cheerful.
That's what I loved about him.
It's funny. Being here together,    the four of us -- it makes me wish    Morn were here, too.
Sure, except we'd have to split    the latinum six ways instead of    five.
Do you mind?
Some people have no respect for    the dead.
Remember that little dance Morn    used to do every time we finished    a job?
You're thinking of someone else.
Get rid of him.
We're closed.
At this hour?
Friends of Morn. We're    commiserating.
I see.    (eyeing Morn's     "friends")    How long are you going to be    closed?
Oh, till about sixteen hundred    hours tomorrow.
We have a lot to commiserate    about.
I see.
Where were we?
I believe that's for me.
Open it.
I'll count it...
All right, someone else count it.
Put it down, Hain. My brother may    be slow, but if you pull the    trigger, he'll kill you.
I'm not slow.
Nahsk... ?
Go ahead, kill each other...
Security! Drop your weapons!
I surrender.
Throw out your weapon.
Take her to a holding cell and get   the rest of them to the Infirmary.
There you are.
Are they gone?
From now on, you'll have to do   your commiserating alone. Your   "friends" are going to prison.
For how long?
Assault with intent to kill --   long enough.
It's mine... all mine.
What you're about to hear is the    most beautiful sound in the    galaxy...
This can't be... there's no   latinum in these bricks...
What?
(as another brick    crumples in his hand)   Someone extracted the latinum...
There's nothing here but worthless    gold...
And it's all yours...
Quark.
Quark.
What do you want?
There's someone here to see you.
I thought you said they were all   going to prison.
You'd better sit down.
Morn?
Alive and well.
Apparently he faked his own death.         I'll let him tell you all about    it.
Well?
I don't want to hear it! Not a    word.
You set me up. You left the    latinum to me because you knew I'd    do whatever it would take to get
I could've been killed, you know.
And I thought we were friends.
I've got to admit, I didn't    suspect for a minute.
To tell you the truth I didn't    think you had it in you to pull    off something like this.
I've just got one question for    you. What happened to the    latinum?
Of course, your second stomach.    You've been keeping it in your    second stomach all these years?        That's a lot of latinum. No    wonder your hair fell out.
For me?        This must be a hundred bricks    worth.
I don't know what to say. Thanks.        Not that I didn't earn it after    what you put me through.
If you ever want to set me up    again, feel free.
You know, you and I should    consider doing business together.
Two enterprising gentlemen like us    could do all right for ourselves.    Take that gold dust of yours...
It doesn't have to be a total    loss. I hear that in certain    primitive cultures it's considered    quite valuable...
